header.matter: Assault/Torture of detained political activists in police holding cells on Fountains Street, Bloem.

testimony: Visser on record.  Allow me Mr Chairman, to apologise for the fact that the witness who gave evidence on Friday, Petrus Miningwa is not present this morning. I knew that one of my witnesses was writing examinations, the mistake I made was not realising that it was Mr Miningwa. He will be back here today by 12 o'clock Mr Chairman.

Mr Visser, you may have made the mistake but someone else on your part did not, and came and spoke to me on Friday afternoon and explained to me that he was writing an examination this morning and requested whether you could continue with someone else and he could come back after the exam and I agreed to that.

I was told Mr Chairman, and I just wanted to place it record, thank you Mr Chairman. May I call the witness Mmelesi, spelled: M - m - e - l - e - s - i.
    There is no affidavit of that witness before you Mr Chairman.

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Mr Mmelesi.

Sorry Mr Chairman.
	Mr Mmelesi, what work do you do?
I'm working at the security branch, Sir.
When did you join the South African Police?
And when did you join the security branch?
I joined the security branch in 1985.
And was that here in Bloemfontein?
What section did you work in the security branch?
Investigation section, Sir. Under Mr Du Plooy.
Who were the other members in that section of the security branch?
Mr Du Plooy, Lieutenant Terreblanche, Warrant Office Paul van den Berg, Sergeant Du Plesis, myself, Constable Kopi, Constable Mafisa.
The time I arrived here, I saw him at the security branch offices.
And as far as your knowledge goes goes what was his position, his status, at that time in 1985?
I thought he was a member of the security branch but I learnt from others that he was a recruit.
Did you ever work together with Mr Ngo?
No Sir, I haven't worked with him.
He was in fact a member of the security branch, was he not?
And did you work with him?
No Sir. We were working all of us working at the security branch but we were working at various sections, I was not working with him in one section.
In 1985 to 1986, can you give us a guesstimate of how many members worked in the security branch here in Bloemfontein?
I just want, I'm sorry, to interrupt you. I just want you to tell us about how many members in total worked in the security branch in Bloemfontein in 1985/86. If you can't remember, just say so.
We were many, I don't remember, I don't remember.

Now, it has been alleged here by Mr Ngo that you participated in the incident which we have referred to in this case as the group of 19 people who were interrogated and detained here in Bloemfontein in 1986.
    Now if it were to be suggested that you did anything wrong, that you performed any illegal or unlawful act, what would you say about that?
I did not take part. The way I had if there was something wrong which I did in that time, I did not assault any person.
Did you see anybody being assaulted in your presence?
No Sir, I did not see a person being assaulted in my presence.
Did you interrogate some of the comrades?
That is correct.  There were those I interrogated, I acted as an interpreter.
Can you remember any of the persons today, that you interrogated at that time or that you interpreted while they were being interrogated at that time?
There were many, I don't remember their names.  When I say there were many, some of them I started to see them now.  I am not able to locate them to the interrogation during that incident.
On how many days - can you remember on how many days you took part in the interrogation as an interpreter?
I'd say I took part in four incidents were I took part in the interrogation as an interpreter, I don't remember well.
You say four incidents. Do you mean four occasions?
It is like this, Sir.  When I say it's four occasions, at some days we'd do our normal work but at times when I was in the office I would help during the interrogation.

I have no further questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER
CROSS-EXAMINATION BY
Mr MMelesi, did you have any contact with Mr Ngo after he was transferred to Pretoria?

No contact whatsoever.
	Thank you, no further questions Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR DU PLESSIS
By that you mean you didn't meet Ngo?
I haven't met Mr Ngo.  I learnt that he was arrested and that he is in Grootvlei Prison.

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Mr Mmelesi, what was the procedure that you followed during these interrogations of the group of 19 persons who were interrogated at the office of the security police?

The method we used in the interrogation we were asking them were they were going then they told us that they were skipping the country to Lesotho. Then we asked them about their contacts or contact, or who was their leader to skip the country.
Were they prepared to give their co-operation throughout?

The way they answered the questions, some of them were prepared to co-operate. Even if some of them were not giving us the direct information we'll take one to give us the clear answers to the questions we asked.
And if he or she did not want to give their co-operation what happened then?
We leave him or her. We take another one.
So you would just leave then, you wouldn't try to press them to give information, you'd just accept that they didn't want to tell you.  Are you asking us to accept that?

No, we were not forcing a person to - the person should just tell us that when he or she was asked those questions we'd leave him and we'd take another one and maybe later we'd go back to that person. There's no way we forced those people.
Now if you returned to the same person later and this person did not want to give his co-operation yet, what then?

I would not say is there after a long time. The way that person has been asked those questions, if you are not satisfied with those questions you'd leave that person to think well that he'd able to understand those questions, Not that he should be forced.
If you've - once you've given him a good chance to think about it and you come back to that man, or to the women, and they still do not want to co-operate, what would happen then?

No, we don't just leave that person like that. I explained that if he or she does not want to give us direct answers we'd take another one so that we'd give that person a chance think the time about the whole incident.
And what happened if after they had time to think they still didn't want to give you answers?

We'd go back to him or her again, we would take her to the interrogation room, then we'd continue with the questioning, then he would he would answer well the way the investigator or the interrogator wants.

I do not understand this. Why would a person let's say that in two occasions this person does not want to co-operate, but for arguments sake at the third stage when he's asked again he co-operates.  Can you explain this to us?  Or is there something else that you did in order to force him to give you those answers?
We did not force a person to explain to us what happened. For the second time when we interrogate he would he would answer those questions well, not that we forced him or her.
I'm afraid I don't understand why somebody who has indicated that they do not want to answer questions, would suddenly decide to answer the questions well.

It will depend on how he is being interrogated.  Let me explain this way.  We'd ask you questions and then you don't answer the questions, later, if you don't understand, we'd call you for a second time, then we'd take another person.
	Then again you'd be asked questions and be told that the answers that we were waiting for for these questions were like this, not that we'd forced that person.

I still do not understand and I do not think the Committee understands. What happened in the meantime to change that persons mind about answering the questions. Because why in the first place, would he not want to answer? And then on a later occasion when he is called in again then he answers to all your questions.

There's nothing we did to that person.  I explained that if a person does not want to answer the questions, we did not force him or her or assault him, we'd leave her or him and take another person, then later would call him or her back without been assaulted, then he would answer those questions.
The Chairman has also asked you and I've asked you for the third time. What led to the fact that this person now replied to your questions or can you not reply to that?

I explained Sir, that we did not force a person or maybe we did not assault that person so that he should answer those questions, it did not work like that.  That person would explained us well with how its being assaulted.
What is the reason for that, do you know or don't you?
No Sir, I did not know, but there was no person who would be able to explain, those people explained what happened.

Do you think there's a possibility that such a person saw what had happened to the others and as a result of the fact that he saw what had happened to the others who did not co-operate who did not co-operate, that he then decided to give some answers? Is that not possibly what could have happened?
I want you to explain to me, to say, when you say maybe he saw what happened to other people in which way can you explain to me?
What I am trying to say is that he saw how the others were assaulted because they did not want to co-operate and that is why at the end of the day, he then gave his or her answers.
I explained Sir, that no person was assaulted in my presence or the one I saw being assaulted. Those people answered to those questions well without being forced.
And did you see the rest of the group there that day as well?
You mean you mean in the office?  Yes, I did.
Was there anyone who gave you an indication as that they had been assaulted?
Have you see - did you see the full group there on another occasion?
Yes, I did the time when they were just about to be taken to where they were going to be detained.
Do you regard frog jumps as part of abuse of the witnesses or don't you?
I did not see people doing frog jumps the way you - the ones you telling me about.
Did you have any shock apparatus?
No Sir, we didn't have those things.
And a black bag which was sometimes used to cover peoples eyes or their heads?
No Sir, I didn't see something like that.
I said that I did not see those kinds of assortments, I did not see them.
Do you know a Oupa Makubalo?
Was he also part of the group that was there that had to be interrogated?
Oupa was present in that group. But where I took part, I did not take part in Oupa's  interrogation.
Were you involved when he had to be taken to a doctor?
If I remember, no.  I dispute that.
It doesn't sound as if you're being sure of the ...[indistinct]
I said I was not present then.
Was he ever taken to a doctor?
I said I was not present and again I don't remember.
What was his condition the condition on the second or the third day after you'd arrested these people?

We did not detain this group. The time when I arrived with Sergeant Du Plessis in the office after lunch, I learnt there were people who were brought here who tried to skip the country and they were arrested in Ladybrand and they were brought to our offices.
The question that I asked was: did you see Oupa Makubalo on the second or the third day after he was arrested, did you see him, again?

I explained that some days I was helping with the investigation and others days we were living out for our normal duty. Myself and Mr Du Plessis would leave the whole day and if I'm present I'd help there if it is necessary. But ...[intervention]
Could you tell us whether you helped on the second day and whether you helped with the interrogation on the third day after they'd been arrested.

That is why I said I don't remember later as whethere I did.  At times, some days we'd leave but if I'm around I'd be able to help with the the interrogation.   At times I'd be there, at times I'd not be there.   As whether it was the second day or the third day, I do not remember.
Did you see him again, Oupa Makubalo, after the first day?
I explained that I do not remember as to whether it is the second or the third day because usually would leave together with Mr Du Plessis. I'm not sure as to whether I was in the office or not.
Did you not see him at all? That is the simple question.
I say I don't know as to whether the second day I was in the office or I was not in the office.

I would like to put it to you Sir, that indeed after the second or third day you took Mr Oupa Makubalo to the doctor because of the fact that he had been assaulted to such an extent that his life was actually in danger at that stage.  Do you deny that or not?

I dispute that.  As I explained that on the first day I saw Oupa Makubalo in the office.  On second day as whether I was in office or not and again on the third day I do not know as whether I'm in the office or not but I I saw him in the office.  But its either on the second day or the third day I was in the office, I'm not sure. That's the way I have explained.
Have these records been made available?
Mr Chair, I am doing my best to get hold of them but I have not been able to do so.  I will see if I could do so soon and place this before the Commission.

If he was taken from the Fountain Street offices, one would expect documentary evidence to that effect to be available.
It seems a little suprising that the, as far as one can gather, because it hasn't been available to us, that no records were kept at Fountain Street and who was taken there for interrogation, when they were sent away and matters of that nature.   Police are usually fairly careful about these things,  
	I raised this question last week about whether there was documentary evidence available and none appears to be forthcoming.  Does this mean that the dockets and other documents no longer exists, if they have been done away with?

Mr Chair I cannot answer to this.  I will do my best by means of the hospital where he had been treated, to see whether any documentation is available.
   I would like to stat to you Mr Mmelesi, that you not only acted as a so called interpreter but that you actively participated in this interrogation of the persons and also the assault of on these persons.
I'm sorry Mr Chairman, may I come in here? Would my learned friend please assist all of us by telling us who it is alleged that this witness assaulted because he hasn't put that.

Just a moment Mr Chair.
    Mr Oliphant do you know him, the person who is known as Chine?
He also alleges that you assaulted him.
He's lying Sir, I did not assault him and I did not assault any person.
Did you also participate in the interrogation of any of the women present there?
Yes, I took part in the interrogation, there may be two or three.  As I explained that the base which I was in office, I took part.
Am I correct if I also say that there were no female interrogators when the females or women where interrogated?  Is that correct?
That is correct, Sir.  Let me explain, Sir, the interrogation room was the person who the interrogator it might be a male and then myself and the person who has been interrogated.
Was there a special interrogation room then?

No, there was the - there were no people in those offices who would use - in their offices as interrogation rooms as interrogation rooms, then that person would sit there, then I would sit on the other side, then the interrogator would sit on the other side.
Please tell me, where you present when Oupa Makubalo at a later stage, was arrested and shots were fired in his direction?
No Sir, I was not present.
Where you on duty on that day?
I was always on duty all the time but I did not take part in that incident.
Did you know that he was arrested on the day and that they returned him to Fountain Street?
Is it possible that you could have been with them and that you just can't remember this?
No Sir, I said I was not there.
Sir, I would like to put it to you that you indeed were in the vehicle which went to arrest him when the shots were fired in his direction.
Sir, I said I was not present there. Understand well, I was not there.
Do know who were all the people who were present?
I know nothing, I was not present.
Did you see when he was brought in?
No Sir, I did not see him.
Can you tell me where your office is in the security branch?
When you enter the 5th floor, it was first one on the left side.
Did you office look out on the so called Violent Street?

The this thing of Violent Street suprises me because that is a passage which goes at the back like when Mr Erasmus - the direction of his - from the door you got the toilet and the toilets for females who are on the left and for male are on the right.  Our offices are facing the direction which I'm looking and the passage go across.
Why was it called this so called Violent Street?
No Sir, it was a sticker which was put on the wall which was written Violent Street.
So the passage wasn't known as Violent Street?
Maybe there are people who call it that but I say the the poster was put there written Violent Street.  The passage was long and it was on those offices in 5th floor.

Because one after the other witness had referred to that passage on the 5th floor as so called Violent Street and some of the police officers who have testified here admitted that. Now I don't understand why you ...[intervention]

Just wait a minute.  I understood the evidence we have heard, we have heard - I can't remember what policeman now, of a passage that his office is in and which then joins another passage which was the one he said was called Violent Street. Is that not the position?  There's more than one passage on that floor?

Mr Chairman, I gained the impression that there was only one passage but perhaps we could ascertain that I may be wrong.
    Could you explain to us the layout of the passages on the 5th floor?

You must listen very carefully Sir.  This is a passage, it goes back and here where I'm pointing its a door, then it turns to the left to those two doors, then that is the toilet, then you turn on the left there's a kitchen.
Which of these two passages which you told us about now was known as the so-called Violent Street?
I don't know perhaps your the best one to tell us Mr Stander, I gather the security police no longer occupy this. The building is there, who are occupies is now?

Mr Chair I can't tell you, I don't know the answer to that question.  As far as I know there are still members of the police force in there but I don't whom exactly but its not far away from here, its approximately a block away.

Wouldn't it be possible, rather than have this confusion and have witnesses trying to persuade, - trying to tell us, for us to adjourn at some stage and walk that block and see what the floor looks like?

Mr Chairman, if I may come in here, Visser on record.  This very thought has occurred to us already last week and we have asked Colonel Erasmus to attempt to make arrangements so that we - we wanted to know first of all whether we'd have access to the building before we approached you with it.
    At, at this stage there is a problem with the 5th floor, apparently there's legislation declaring an off limits area to to the public.  I'm not sure in what or some such, its got something to do with National Intelligence, Mr Chairman.
    We are attempting, I think Mr Chairman, I am speaking under correction, but we are attempting to obtain permission to enter the 5th floor, that's the one thing, but in any event, what we are attempting to do is to obtain floor plans of each and every floor and to give that at least to you.
    But we are working on getting us into the building there's just a problem with the 5th floor as I understand the position to be at the moment but we're working on that very issue Mr Chairman.

The 5th floor is really the only one we want to see, we don't want to get into the building as such but if we could do that perhaps cross-examination as to the details of the geography of the floor could stand over until we know whether we can see it ourselves or get a proper floor plan.
Thank you Mr Chair.  Before I step down from this aspect, let us then call this passage with the board Violent Street and ask the question whether your office actually faced on this passage.
: The door of the office we were occupying faced the passage and this passage proceeded ...[intervention]
What did you call that passage?  Did it have a name, for instance: Peace Street or whatever?

This passage did not have a name, Sir.  The only thing that was there was a sticker put on the wall and I do not know who put that sticker there.  I call it a passage, it did not have a name.  The sticker was called Violent Street but that was not the name of that passage.
Was the sticker in your passage or did it point towards the other passage?
It can't be correct because I've asked you was the sticker in your passage or did it point towards the other passage?
Sir, I explained that there were two passages, there's a door, there's a passage going to the right and the other one going to the left.
The sticker, was it pointing to the passage going to the right?
The passage to the left when you were going to the kitchen.
Did you ever enquire about this sticker on the door on the wall?

No Sir. I tried to ask what was happening with that sticker but no-one gave me a clear indication of why the sticker was put on the wall. All the members could see that, I do not know whether the sticker is still there or not.
You didn't go to any trouble to remove it because according to your testimony it had no meaning whatsoever. Do I understand you correctly?
I do not know, Sir, but I just saw it as a sticker that was put on the wall.
Could you have removed it yourself, had you so wished?
The problem was I did not know who was the person who put it there. And I did not take that into consideration.
You also didn't go to any trouble to enquire about it?

I would like to state it to you Sir, that that sticker had been placed on that wall because people were continuously assaulted and tortured in that passage and that is why it was known as Violent Street.  Could you reply to that?
Do you deny it or don't you?
I dispute that, I never seen anyone assaulted in that passage.

No further questions to the witness.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR STANDER
Mr Mmelesi, as of 6th of April 1986, was your floor on the 5th floor or was it on the 4th floor?
We were on the 5th floor, Sir.

And on that day you worked with Terreblanche
and Du Plooy, didn't you?
When I arrived at the security branch I worked with those people you just mentioned.
Perhaps you could tell him what the 6th of April was. I can't remember what the 6th of April 1986 was.
This is the day when the 19 people were ...[intervention]

I thought its common cause Mr Chair.
	 And this is the day on which the 19 people were detained. Do you remember that now?
Sir, I do not remember when it comes to dates but I remember that there were people brought to the offices.
Now, on that day, when these people were detained, did you assist the officers on the 4th floor?
I helped in the investigation department to ask those people questions.
Where did you help the investigation department?
On the 4th floor, that is where the investigation was done, we were in the 5th floor.
And who - which white officer were you working with?
Its a long time Sir, I do not remember but the person I was working with very well was Sergeant Du Plessis but he was not involved in the interrogation section.
Now, I'm talking about this particular day. Who did you work with on that particular day?
Sir, I said I do not remember well because this happened long time ago.
How many people did you interrogate on that day?
On that day, i think two, if not four.
I do not remember them, Sir.
Did you get any information from these people?
The way the interrogator proceeded he was satisfied with the answers.
Was he satisfied with all of them as and when he started interrogating each of them?
On that day where I participated, he asked them questions and they explained to him well what  happened, why they decided to leave, he was satisfied. I was an interpreter.
In short, all of them co-operated?  None of them at any stage did not co-operate?
Where I took part, I said they satisfied him.  No-one was stubborn, they all answered questions without being forced.
And they co-operated from the onset is what I'm putting you, why can't you say yes or no?
I said yes I've explained that if a person did not want to co-operate then but I said the time when I was there nobody was not co-operating, they answered those questions well.
You see, earlier on your evidence was that people were asked questions and those who did not co-operate was taken upstairs and then they would be called for the second time.

I'm sorry, I have to object Mr Chairman, the questions which he answered, and I attempted to listen very carefully, were put to him on the hypothesis that if somebody refused to answer questions, what would you then do?   And he said the answer which my learned friend has now given, he has not been asked by anybody until right now, whether the people did in fact co-operate. There's a difference, Mr Chairman.

My recollection is he said he was asked what sort of [End of tape 1, side A - no follow on sound]  I aske him who their leaders and contacts were, some were prepared to co-operate, others were not, we would just leave them.  We would just leave them.
    Let me later go back to these people ...[intervention]
That, with respect, is my note Mr Chairman.

I do think it's fair to say though, that his answers were all speculative always if, if, if.  I don't think that he in that portion of evidence said that they did in fact do this, this is what they would have done.
Thank you, Mr Chairman, that is I think, what I tried to convey.

My understanding Mr Chair, was that the context in which the words if and would were used were not used in a speculative sense but they were used to explain what what would occur as what occurred in fact on that day.
    It was not only hypothesis. It was what did you do what would you do if people did not co-operate on that day?  They were specific to what would happen on that day.
Well Mr Chairman, I don't want to waste time.  Let him put the question to the witness and let the witness field for himself.
In any event it has emerged that you told us that some people did not co-operate on that day and that is contrary to what you just put that none of them did not co-operate.

I did not say they were not co-operating. You asked me, saying: "If people did not answer questions what did they do"?, I answered and said: "Those who did not want to ask questions would just leave them and ask others. And later would bring them back and interrogate them and they would answer those questions well".
Now mister, - I'll leave the rest of the things for argument.  The next that I wanted to ask you is where - in which office where you on that day?
We were on the 4th floor the time when we were interrogating these people.  This thing happened a long time ago, I don't know whose office - I don't remember whose office was that.
And who was present with you?  You say you don't recall that as well.
I did not - I don't remember as to whether whom I was assisting in the interrogation.
You don't recall who was with you, you don't recall in which office you were and you don't recall who you interrogated on that day?
I explained that it happened a long time ago, I don't remember.  I would not say it's this person or that person because there were many.
You don't recall whether people co-operated immediately or not?

You asked me a question as to - the first person asked me as to whether those people were co-operating or not.  I'd say were I was they were co-operating, where a took part as an interpreter, those people were co-operative.
I find it strange, in the light of the fact that you have forgotten so many things that you can recall that you arrived in the office at 1 o'clock.

That is so because on that day I was together with Mr Du Plessis.  We were going to investigate then after lunch we came back to the office. And when we arrived there Mr Du Plessis told us that the ...[inaudible]
And what time did you leave work on that day?
Did you actually knock off at 4 o'clock on that day?
I say we knock off at 4 o'clock.  On that day we took them to where they were supposed to be detained.
And the evidence was that the detainees were taken to the various police stations after 5.
I explained that on that day, usually we knock off at 4 o'clock but on that day we did not knock off at 4 o'clock.  We were supposed to take those people where they were supposed to be detained.
But why didn't you say that a moment ago when I asked you whether - what time did you knock off, you said - why did you not then just say we knock off at 4 o'clock?
That is like that.   I say usually we knock off at 4 o'clock but on that day we were supposed to - we did not go home, we were supposed to take those people to where they were supposed to be locked.

Counsel asked you specifically how do you remember you remember you arrived there at 1 o'clock, and you told us you'd been working with DuPlessis and when you arrived back after lunch you were told about this.  Counsel then said what time did you knock off that day and you said 4 o'clock.
Let me clear it off.  We usually knock off at 4 o'clock, but at on that day we did not knock off at 4 o'clock, we were supposed to take those people were they were detained.
Now, where did you take them?
We took them to Glen, if I remember well.
With whom did you go to Glen?
I don't remember because we were many, we took them with cars and Kombis. I don't know  which Kombis because some of them were not more in use.
And you don't recall the other person who was present when you took the persons except yourself.
We went with Kopi, Mafisa and Lieutenant Terreblanche, Warrant Officer Swanapoel.  I explained that with whom I was working during that time.

The question is: "On that day, can you remember with whom did you - did you go with a Kombi yourself?  Who was driving the Kombi?  Where you guarding the detainees?  What was your function in that Kombi or motor car or whatever you've been in? You yourself.
I said I did not - I don't remember as to who was driving and where was I sitting but what I know is that we took these people to where they were detained.
I don't remember with whom I was within that group.

Thank you Mr Chair.
	Do you remember if Mr Motsamai was there?
Sir, I said we were many I do not remember as whether other people from various sections helped or not.
My instructions are that the only people you took prisoners were yourself, Kopi and Motsamai.  ...[inaudible] can you because you can't remember?
I said its like that but I do not remember. The we were those people were many.
There were 19 all in all. I do not remember who was there on that day and who was not there on that day.
There were only three policemen, yourself, Kopi and Motsamai.
I said I do not remember whether other members from various sections helped to take these people to where they were supposed to be detained. I don't remember well.
And Mr Memanie, were they all travelling together in one vehicle, all 19 detainees and the three policemen?

My instructions are that it was not all 19 that were travelling in the same vehicle that Motsamai, Mmelesi and Kopi were.
    Now, Mr Mmelesi, for how long did you see Mr Ngo at security branch?
I don't remember, but I'd say it may be a month or two, I don't remember.
...[inaudible] period, a lengthy period, longer than two months.
No it might not be more that two months.
And at that stage you believed that he was a member of the security branch?
The time when I arrived in the office he was there, I just took it that he was a member of the security branch but when I enquired they told be that he is a recruit.
Yes, he was working as if he's a permanent staff member, that is why I regarded him as a member.
And I want us to go back to the passage. I  I got the impression that the 5th floor forms an L.  Is that correct?
That is correct.  As I've explained that this passage would go this way, and here is a door and then it would go towards the main entrance.
